content.description: This has big jugs, great feet, and is a bit reachy. A set of jugs about halfway up the route are a little weak and could pull off in the near future.
content.protection: A two bolt anchor on top.
content.location:
It is about 15 feet right of the

TR Wall OW

.

content.description: This can probably be done easily with stemming or liebacking but was most fun with some fist jams and the feet in the crack. Enter the chimney to finish.
content.protection: #5 Camalot and some slung 2x4s cut to the appropriate length.
content.location:
It is just right of the

TR Wall Left Route

.

content.description: This is an easy, fun route up the face.
content.protection: There are anchors at the top. Walk around to set up a TR.
content.location: It is downhill and east from the Eggs.

climbs.name: Think Big
climbs.fa: Ryando Smithman? It's 3 Sisters, so I dunno

content.description:
Start on the obvious, large jug used for '

T-Rex

'. Everything right of the sidepull/gaston crimp on the face and left of the arete is off. Climb straight up using said crimps and slopers.
content.protection: A pad.
content.location:
This is on the same wall as

T-Rex

and

Bloody Thumbs

.

content.description: Sit start with your left hand in a good pocket and your right hand on a crimp. Throw to the lip, get some feet, and REACH for the crappy sloper up and to the left. Mantel finish. The crack to the left is off, but other than that, have fun!
content.protection: A pad. The tree helps.
content.location: Located on the Choss Block, which can be found by walking 50 yards behind The Toprope Wall.

content.description: Start down low matched on the large jugs. Get some high feet and crank up to the slopey jug. Top out. I think it is worth the effort.
content.protection: A pad would be nice.
content.location: It is on the same rockband as the Toprope Wall, about 100 yards before The Wave Wall.

content.description: Follow the easy line up and to the right.  A bush will be all up in your business for the topout.
content.protection: A pad and spotter to move said pad.
content.location: It is on the left side facing the TR wall.

content.description:
Start on two obvious chalked holds on the right side of the overhang about chest height. Pick a left foot (the flat slab and wall right of the crack are off), pull on, traverse left across the overhung face using an undercling, a slope, and the small crimp. Once you reach the arete, finish up

Does Anyone Remember Lisa Loeb?
content.protection: A pad or two.
content.location:
This is on the rock formation just off the trail leading to the Trailside Egg and Upper Eggs. This problem adds 3-4 powerful moves into the established arete problem,

Does Anyone Remember Lisa Loeb?

content.description: Start matched on the rail below the horizontal crack with low feet. Make a fun throw straight up over the lip, and follow the direct route to the bulging jugs to top out. Avoid holds off of the central route (see the photo). This is fun!
content.protection: None.
content.location:
Begin a few feet to the left of the starting jug of

T-Rex

.

content.description: Squeeze up in the slot and get your feet up to reach some holds back up in there.  It's fairly committing.
content.protection: A pad and a spotter. You could slip out of the slot and end up landing on your back.
content.location: It is on the left side facing the TR Wall.

content.description:
Start at a jug, go up to a left sloper, then move to a right sloper and up over the bulge. It has a cruxy top and a funky landing around the rocks below. Donâ€™t use holds or feet of

National Geographic

.
content.protection: A couple pads and a spotter.
content.location:
It climbs the rock right of

National Geographic

.

content.description:
Start as for

Say Cheese

, but instead of going up towards the bush, traverse over with holds at about eye level, then dropping down to the start of

T-Rex

and

Around The Horn

. The crux is just before the starting hold of

T-Rex

, and involves a hidden undercling, a lot of body tension, and a little luck. Shake out and finish with Around The Horn. There is a harder variation (that I did not do) that continues through some sharp crimps onto the Top Rope Wall. This variation was FA'd in the 90's and goes at solid V5.
content.protection: Pretty low, but you could definitely use a pad at the crux.
content.location: On the Top Rope cliff band about 50 yards down from The Wave Wall, you should see the wall to the right of the trail when heading toward the Trailside Egg.

climbs.name: Does Anyone Remember Lisa Loeb?
climbs.fa: Jarred Swiontek? Give me the heads up if (as I'm sure there has been) there's been a prior FA.

content.description:
Follow the obvious holds up the arete.  The crack that forms the upper end of "

Amazon

" is off.  Top out on a gritty, sloped top.
content.protection: A pad.
content.location:
This is on the rock formation just off of the trail leading up to the Trailside Egg and the Upper Eggs, just to the right of the problem "

Amazon

".

content.description: Work your way up past some crimps to a hand jam, get some feet, gain the jugs at the top.
content.protection: A pad. Watch out for the rock at the base.
content.location:
It is the first route you see on the approach to the toprope wall on the same block as

National Geographic

.

Per

Alex Head

: this is the leftmost route on the Non Eggs and the first route prominent route you can see on the left side of the boulder. Start in a small cave between two boulders in a sit-start position on the right side, match hands on the sloper.

content.description: Only use holds to the left of and including the vertical crack.  Skank some beta from the pictures if you want.
content.protection: A pad and a helmet.
content.location:
It is in the middle left facing the TR wall and right of

T-Rex

.

content.description: Passively place your right hand in the slot, and then get your feet up to probably grab the undercling flake with your left.
content.protection: No pad. This must be done with no pad.
content.location: It is located on the Choss Block, baby, which is 50 yards to the east of The Toprope Wall.

content.description:
Climb the low traverse into

Bloody Thumbs

. This is no harder than V6.

Start on two sharp crimps at eye level. Find some feet, reach/toss for another crimp with the right, grab a gaston, and top out. It is short but sustained. Also, there is a V6/V7 variation that begins where the low traverse does and finishes with this climb.
content.protection: A couple of pads. Nice, flat landing.
content.location:
It is between

Flightless Pigeons

and

Around the Horn

.

climbs.name: Bloody Knuckles
climbs.fa: Ryando Smithman? It's 3 sisters, so I dunno

content.description:
Bloody Knuckles is an eliminate. Start on large jug used for '

T-Rex

'. Cross into sidepull crimp, and throw for the jug used to top out on '

T-Rex

'. All other holds are off.
content.protection: A pad.
content.location:
This is on the same wall as

T-Rex

and

Bloody Thumbs

.

content.description: Use the jugs to go up and around the bulge. This is a great problem.
content.protection: A pad.
content.location: It is on the left on the rock band we like to call The TR Wall.

content.description: Start on the large, chalked up hold, move to some sidepulls, exit on easier terrain. Not as good as its neighbor, but still worth the effort. There is a much harder slopey route that goes off to the right.
content.protection: A pad.
content.location: One of the first routes you see as you approach the toprope wall.

content.description:
Start on a large crimp between

Amazon

and

Discovery

. Avoid the large crack holds on either side, and climb using good foot holds and very bad hand holds, including a right-facing crimp and a shallow two finger dish. Continue up on easier terrain avoiding the cracks.

If someone has climbed this before I will happily update, although there was absolutely no chalk on these holds it seems like too obvious not to try.
